item.title: Expert in Local Development/Local Governance – Category II
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
With the aim to provide the Lebanese Authorities, beneficiaries of the EU funded programmes with an overall, independent and accountable result-oriented Ex-post Evaluation of :

  • “ Appui au développement local dans le nord du Liban” – ENPI/2008/19-623 – Component Community Development : a selection of 5 projects implemented by the European Social Development Fund (ESFD);
  • “ Support for economic recovery I : Local development, reconstruction, infrastructure rehabilitation” – ENPI/2007/18-882 – Component Local Development Projects : the 12 projects implemented by the Unions of Municipalities (UoM);
  • “ Local Authorities in Development” : a selection of 6 projects.

The objective of this assignment is threefold:

  • To assess the implementation of the interventions, paying a particular attention to the results of the project against its objectives;
  • To assess the impact of the programmes compared to the initial objectives;
  • To propose key lessons and recommendations for the Lebanese Authorities to prepare a strategy and design orientation interms of support to local development and for the future EU interventions in order to improve current and upcoming actions in the field of local development/local governance in Lebanon.

Expert in Local Development/Local Governance – Category II

Qualifications and skills:

At least Masters Degree in economics, social science, or equivalent; in its absence equivalent professional experience of 10 years.

General professional experience:

  • Experience in implementing programmes aiming at improving local governance is compulsory;
  • At least six (6) years of experience in sectors related to lot 7 (i.e. technical description), in addition to the minimum expertise common to all lots, is compulsory.

Specific professional experience:

  • Experience as evaluator in the local development field in at least 1 project/programme;
  • Experience as evaluator in the local development field of an EU funded project/programme is an asset;
  • Experience in Mediterranean countries and knowledge of Middle East political context;
  • Knowledge of EU project cycle management, EU procedures.

Soft skills:

Excellent writing and editing skills.

Language skills:

Excellent command of Arabic and English is compulsory;

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Adeline_VanHoutte@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.title: Expert in Socio-Economic Development – Category I
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
With the aim to provide the Lebanese Authorities, beneficiaries of the EU funded programmes with an overall, independent and accountable result-oriented Ex-post Evaluation of :

  • “ Appui au développement local dans le nord du Liban” – ENPI/2008/19-623 – Component Community Development : a selection of 5 projects implemented by the European Social Development Fund (ESFD);
  • “ Support for economic recovery I : Local development, reconstruction, infrastructure rehabilitation” – ENPI/2007/18-882 – Component Local Development Projects : the 12 projects implemented by the Unions of Municipalities (UoM);
  • “ Local Authorities in Development” : a selection of 6 projects.

The objective of this assignment is threefold:

  • To assess the implementation of the interventions, paying a particular attention to the results of the project against its objectives;
  • To assess the impact of the programmes compared to the initial objectives;
  • To propose key lessons and recommendations for the Lebanese Authorities to prepare a strategy and design orientation interms of support to local development and for the future EU interventions in order to improve current and upcoming actions in the field of local development/local governance in Lebanon.

Expert in Socio-Economic Development – Category I

Qualifications and skills:

At least Masters Degree in economics, social science, or equivalent; in its absence equivalent professional experience of at least 16 years.

General professional experience:

  • Experience in implementing programmes aiming at reducing poverty and promoting development at local level is compulsory;
  • At least twelve (12) years of experience in sectors related to lot 7 (i.e. technical description),
  • in addition to the minimum expertise common to all lots, is compulsory.

Specific professional experience:

  • Experience as evaluator in the socio-economic field in at least 3 programmes;
  • Experience as evaluator in the socio-economic field of an EU funded programme is an asset;
  • Experience in Mediterranean countries and knowledge of Middle East political context can be an asset;
  • Sound knowledge of EU project cycle management, EU procedures.

Soft skills:

Excellent writing and editing skills.

Language skills:

  • Excellent command of English and Arabic is compulsory;
  • Ability to communicate in French desirable.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Adeline_VanHoutte@dai.com

item.title: Junior Expert - Security Sector Management Expert
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Final Evaluation: Security Sector Reform Programme (SSRP)

The final evaluation is expected to provide decision-makers in the Government of Jamaica, the relevant external cooperation services, the relevant external cooperation services of the EC and the wider public with sufficient information to:

  • Make an overall independent assessment of the performance of the programme, paying particular attention to the impact of the programme actions against its objectives;
  • Identify key lessons ad recommendations to guide future programmes especially those under the 11th EDF and to propose practical recommendations on the feasibility of the implementation of future policy support/sector budget support programmes

Junior Expert - Security Sector Management Expert

  • University Education;
  • Solid knowledge and practical experience (minimum 3 years) in developing, operating and managing security and justice programmes in developing countries preferably in Small Island Developing States;
  • Sound experience of implementing both physical infrastructure and institutional capacity building.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to francesca_giordano@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Final Evaluation: Security Sector Reform Programme (SSRP)

Sector Budget Support Expert, Senior (TL)

  • Solid knowledge of and practical experience in (minimum 10 years) designing and implementing Secto Wide Programmes preferably in the Security Sector in Developing countries;
  • Ideally with experience in the Caribbean;
  • Experience working with a wide variety of implementing partners and stakeholders
  • Experience with the EU Sector Policy Support Programming Approach; feasibility studies and evaluation;
  • Be well versed in project evaluation methods and techniques, EC experience is an advantage;
  • Sound experience of implementing both physical infrastructure and institutional capacity building.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to francesca_giordano@dai.com

item.title: Team Leader, Law & Justice Sector, Papua New Guinea
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Objectives of the role:

The Team Leader will manage and support a team of technical and operational staff to deliver a highly complex and important DFAT investment to support law and justice in Papua New Guinea. The program will build on Australian support to the sector from the Papua New Guinea-Australia Law and Justice Partnership, which was completed in June 2014 and its ensuing Transition Program, which runs from July 2014 to December 2015.

The program will target agencies along with sub-national institutions and stakeholders in Hela, Southern Highlands, Gulf, Western, Oro and Morobe provinces, plus the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (ARB).

The Team Leader will establish and manage relationships with both potential and identified stakeholders, and will facilitate and coordinate collaboration with other development programs being implemented by DFAT and other donors.

Length of the project: 2016 - 2019 Start Date: August 2015 (to support the mobilisation and transition phase)

Criteria:

  • A tertiary degree in a relevant field (e.g. international development, international law);
  • Demonstrated experience in capacity development techniques (related to technical skills) and the ability to use a variety of approaches to increase the skills and service delivery standards of partner agencies, counterparts and team members.
  • High level interpersonal skills including verbal and written communication skills and an ability to produce high quality technical reports, guidance notes and templates.
  • Demonstrated ability to lead teams of professionals and to coach and mentor junior staff members, and work effectively with others to build strong partnerships and contribute to sustainable outcomes.
  • Demonstrated ability to work sensitively in a complex multi-cultural environment and high levels of personal resilience to work successfully in remote and challenging locations.
  • Demonstrated experience in implementing governance programs in decentralised service delivery contexts and familiarity and understanding of working with law and justice agencies and community justice initiatives;
  • Demonstrated experience in leading organisational development and change management processes;
  • Ability to mainstream gender-sensitive programming and anti-corruption initiatives within program design and implementation;
  • Demonstrated capacity to manage a transitional mobilisation phase in which the managing contractor changes;
  • An outstanding history of working with the Australian Aid program and the Department for Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT);
  • Prior experience in Papua New Guinea and the Pacific region.

How to apply: Please send your CV by email to Sarah_Owen@dai.com. Please note that due to high volumes of applications, we cannot guarantee to respond to each applicant.

“Please note that all profiles are indicative only and therefore subject to change once the ToR is made available.”

item.title: Expert on Women's Rights and Violence against Women (category II)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Scoping Mission for Pakistan Gender Programme

To assist the EUD and relevant government stakeholders in identifying possible designs for two projects or one combined project to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment and to combat violence against women in one or several province(s) of Pakistan.

Expert on Women’s Rights and Violence against Women (category II)

  • The expert should hold a masters degree in gender studies, sociology, social anthropology, political science or other relevant field, or have at least 2 additional years of work experience in the equivalent area.
  • The expert must have proven experience of working on the prevention of violence against women. Experience working on women’s empowerment and on domestic violence will be valued
  • The expert should demonstrate the ability to engage with a variety of stakeholders and be able to quickly familiarise themselves with Pakistan’s human rights infrastructure, especially when it comes to women’s rights. She/He should be familiar with the primary international legal instruments on women’s rights.
  • ***Local expertise is essential*
  • Expert must be Fluent English (written and spoken)
  • Expert must be Fluent in Urdu or with knowledge of Pashto, Sindhi, Punjabi or other local language of Pakistan.**

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to chloe_messenger@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.title: Expert in Gender Rights (category 1)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Scoping Mission for Pakistan Gender Programme

To assist the EUD and relevant government stakeholders in identifying possible designs for two projects or one combined project to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment and to combat violence against women in one or several province(s) of Pakistan.

Expert in Gender Rights (category 1)

  • The expert should hold a masters degree in gender studies, sociology, social anthropology, political science or other relevant field, or have at least 2 additional years of work experience in the equivalent area.
  • The expert must have proven experience of working on gender equality in South Asia.
  • Previous work on women in the labour force and/or prevention of domestic violence is an advantage.
  • Experience should be gained through previous work not exclusively in the civil society sector.
  • The expert should be familiar with grassroots consultation methodologies such as focus group discussions, most significant change method, etc.
  • good understanding of international human rights law and in-depth knowledge of women’s rights in international law and practice, as well as experience working in this field in South Asia
  • Experience in other developing economies with similar development indicators and gender gap indexes, as well as comparable levels of poverty and education may be considered.
  • The expert should have experience developing at least two EU or other European donor project designs and be familiar with the United Nations system and working methods.
  • **Local expertise is essential
  • Expert must be Fluent English (written and spoken)
  • Expert must be Fluent in Urdu or with knowledge of Pashto, Sindhi, Punjabi or other local language of Pakistan.**

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to chloe_messenger@dai.com

item.title: Expert on Labour Rights and Economic Empowerment (category 1)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Scoping Mission for Pakistan Gender Programme

To assist the EUD and relevant government stakeholders in identifying possible designs for two projects or one combined project to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment and to combat violence against women in one or several province(s) of Pakistan.

Expert on Labour Rights and Economic Empowerment (category 1)

  • The expert should hold a masters degree in economics, sociology, social anthropology, political science or other relevant field, or have at least 2 additional years of work experience in the equivalent area.
  • proven experience of working on labour rights and labour standards from a rights-based perspective, including economic empowerment of disadvantaged groups
  • extensive experience working on economic empowerment projects, which did not centre on vocational training, micro-finance or merely awareness
  • in-depth understanding of the rights based approach to development and be fully conversant with the linkages between economic empowerment, women’s participation in the work force and poverty alleviation
  • good understanding of basic international human rights law and in-depth understanding of the core ILO conventions, as well as experience working in this field in South Asia
  • Experience in other developing economies with similarly large informal sectors and comparable levels of poverty and education may be considered
  • Experience working on gender equality in labour is a strong asset.
  • The expert should have experience developing at least two EU or other European donor project designs and be familiar with the United Nations system and working methods
  • Local expertise is essential
  • Fluent English (written and spoken)
  • Fluent in Urdu or with knowledge of Pashto, Sindhi, Punjabi or other local language of Pakistan.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to chloe_messenger@dai.com

item.title: Senior Expert on EU Procurement
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
The overall objective is to provide technical assistance to the procurement of services and supplies within the TCP-RNR project.

Senior Expert on EU Procurement

Minimum requirements:

Education and skills:

  • University degree in economics, law, social sciences, rural development or natural resources discipline;
  • Specialisation in public procurement or EU procurement rules;
  • Fluency in English;

General Professional experience:

  • At least 12 years in the field of EU procurement as an advisor, consultant, EU official or public employee.

Specific professional experience:

  • Participation in at least 3 EU projects as a procurement expert during the last 8 years;
  • Participation in at least 2 international restricted service tenders, 3 negotiated service tender procedures and at least 2 local supply tender procedures as a procurement advisor or administrator responsible for revising the ToRs and the tender dossier;
  • Has been a trainer in at least 2 PRAG trainings for Beneficiaries or EU Funds;
  • Has participated in at least 1 programme estimate project as consultant, administrator or Imprest accountant.

Meeting the following criteria is an advantage:

  • Previous experience in Asia
  • Experience in Bhutan and familiarity with Ministry of Agriculture and Forests of Bhutan
  • Experience in trainings and CB related to renewable resources and agriculture development.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Agnese_Ortolani@dai.com

item.title: AWP 2 Projects Review
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
The Beyond WTO Program (B-WTO) was developed in response to a request from the Government of Vietnam (GoV) for donor support to help with managing economic integration and the transition to a market economy following WTO accession. The B-WTO goal is “to strengthen government’s capacity to manage the integration of Vietnam into the global economy and the transition of Vietnam to a socialist market economy”. The immediate objective is “implementation of priority policy actions from the GoV’s Action Plan to enhance Vietnam’s capacity to sustain pro-poor growth (GAP)”.

The remit of this project was a review of the 2nd annual work plan’s implementation (AWP2) of Phase 2 of the B-WTO in May 2013. The objectives of the review were to:

  • Evaluate the project implementation performance and project results relative to the logical framework targets and evaluation criteria.
  • Evaluate the results achieved at the Component and Program’s level according to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework of the Program.
  • Identify lessons learned from implementation, make recommendations for the remaining duration of the program and the Independent Completion Report process.

item.title: Health Program M&E
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Program 2013 Performance and Quality Mapping Exercise
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: AusAID’s PNG Program is looking to improve its performance and quality (P&Q) standards and systems. The purpose of this project was to map the PNG Program’s current P&Q capacity and systems, to address the risk of AusAID being unable to demonstrate results for its increased investments in PNG over the next four years. Over the last several years, the PNG Program has undertaken a number of M&E assessments and reviews which have identified key strengths and challenges within the program. This project was intended to pick up where these assessments left off. Through a desk review and consultations with sector teams, the Review Team were to distil key P&Q risks and issues for the PNG Program. The Review Team’s brief included the provision of recommendations on priority activities to support sector approaches to M&E, strengthen the Program’s ability to collect evidence, provide critical analysis and report on results.

item.title: Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
AusAID required a consultant to assist with the development and finalisation of its Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework. Development of a humanitarian monitoring and evaluation framework is a key commitment outlined in AusAID’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy (HAP) and its associated Implementation Plan. In line with the agency focus on results reporting, the HAP and HAP Implementation Plan commit AusAID to develop a monitoring and evaluation framework to support the initial performance assessment framework contained within the HAP and AusAID annual reporting under the Comprehensive Aid Policy Framework.

The key objective of this assignment was to build the Humanitarian program’s capacity for monitoring and reporting results by:

  • In consultation with AusAID’s Humanitarian team, redraft and finalise the Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework, to ensure it provides a platform to:
  • Track implementation of key commitments in Australia’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy; and,
  • Establish a set of measurable humanitarian performance indicators (in addition to the two CAPF indicators) to enable AusAID to track achievements, lessons learned and to report on the results achieved from AusAID’s humanitarian work.

item.title: Review of Pacific Forum Compact Reporting
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: The purpose of the assignment was to examine country views of aid effectiveness and regional organisations expressed through Forum Compact reporting, particularly peer review of Forum Island Countries’ national development plan processes. The services provided included the preparation of a think piece which outlines key aid effectiveness issues arising from country reporting under the Compact reporting and discusses options for addressing these issues.

item.title: Health Program M&E Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Study on Community-based Social Protection
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
Poverty and Social Analysis is the process of using and generating evidence on poverty throughout the aid management cycle. Most poverty and social analysis focuses on economic and human capital, but there are two oft neglected elements: voice and influence, and social capital. Yet more and more development practitioners are recognizing the importance of social capital, particularly informal social capital, in preventing and addressing poverty and vulnerability.

This project supported AusAID to explore:

  • the role of informal social capital in the Fijian context and whether it lends itself to fair redistribution of resources and, if so, the ways in which AusAID can engage with local communities to strengthen existing social capital structures
  • how such structures can enable the disempowered and poor to claim their entitlements in the three domains discussed in the PSA framework
  • the potential challenges that can arise from such efforts. For instance, the poorest are often included on less favorable terms within social networks, and have access to fewer and lower-quality networks. Further, we need to better understand how poverty and disempowerment intersect with an absence of informal social capital, the repercussions this has, and the options available for tackling this.

item.title: Provision of a Child Protection Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
For this project HTSPE was contracted to provide a child protection specialist and handle all the associated management and administrative work.

The child protection specialist provided by HTSPE was required to work on an assignment designed to assist the Pacific Division (PACD) to improve its approach to child protection and managing risks to children. AusAID has a number of partners in the Pacific who work with children or come into contact with children through their activities. The AusAID-wide child protection stocktake, conducted in May 2013 found that there are a number of organisations funded by AusAID in the Pacific with a high or very high inherent child protection risk. Consistent with the stocktake report PACD proposes to escalate efforts to ensure partner organisations policies, procedures and practices are in accordance with AusAID’s Child Protection Policy 2013 and to make child protection a more explicit focus of PACD’s risk management system.

item.title: Senior Environment and Biology Expert (Category I)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
The Expert 2 is expected to contribute the implementation of all of the related modules and the preparation of both training materials and Training Evaluation Report in the context of related chapter/s.

Qualifications and skills:

  • Master’s degree in Biology, Ecology, Chemistry or other Natural Sciences related to assignment. In the absence of the degree required, at least 17 years of professional experience in the related areas is requested.
  • Good command of both written and spoken English.
  • General professional experience
  • At least 12 years of experience in the sector(s) related to the Lot.

Specific professional experience:

  • At least 3 years of experience in technical and/or scientific fields required for the implementation of the Water Framework Directive and/or Habitat Directive and/or other related Directives.
  • At least 2 river basin management plans experience in terms of setting of environmental objectives and/or setting, design and upgrade of biological monitoring programme and/or execution and assessment of biological monitoring.
  • Experience in development of measures for water pollution reduction and/or improving ecological status, and/or river basin characterisation/analysis will be an asset.
  • Experience in projects related to Integrated Water Resources Management will be an asset.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Agnese_Ortolani@dai.com
